author: karalabe

content: Guillaume said "stateless"

author: karalabe

author: karalabe
content: There's no noticable difference over the past 5 days in block processing

author: karalabe
content: One possible solution I can think of is if a mining pool switched over from Parity to Geth

author: karalabe
content: We have a very very aggressive inclusion logic in Geth so that no valid PoW solution goes to waste

author: karalabe
content: Essentially we track all past blocks (7 old) that we ever sent to miners, and will accept solutions as uncles for them until they exceed the 7 block limit

author: karalabe
content: The rationale is that GPUs only fetch new works every few secs, so there's a chance you are mining on a stale block

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <vbuterin> so the real uncle rate is higher than the on-chain uncle rate and before there were uncles that were completely slipping away?

author: karalabe
content: AFAIK parity does not have this mechanism

author: karalabe
content: (I may be horribly worng)

author: karalabe
content: but yes, that would be my initial hunch

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <vbuterin> right, but if a few parity miners ignore an uncle wouldn't the first geth miner pick it up?

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <vbuterin> 8 is plenty of time for that to usually work

author: karalabe
content: if the uncle is mined by geth, then yes, geth will pick it up. the slippage is before that

author: karalabe
content: without this mechanism, a node will not accept **its own mined** uncle if it's an older block

author: karalabe
content: and thus never even announce it

author: karalabe
content: that's how geth worked until 1.9.0, the only solutions accepted were for the currently active mining task, solutions to older tasks were dropped

author: karalabe
content: so if say parity still does it like that, then "finishing a pow" for an older block would be wasted effort and discarded without ever being assembled into an uncle and announced

author: karalabe
content: switching to geth would collect all these slipped away valid solutions

author: karalabe
content: Here's a scenario where this might have happened:

author: karalabe
content: https://etherscan.io/block/9733865

author: karalabe
content: 65, 64 and 64's sibling was all mined by ethermine

author: karalabe
content: so option a) the two 64's were mined by different backing nodes (e.g. EU vs US)

author: karalabe
content: option b) both 64s were mined by the same backing node; but that requires the aggressive inclusion logic of tracking stale work packages sent out, tht could still result in valid uncles

author: karalabe
content: but all in all this is one hunch, it might be totally off

author: karalabe
content: one possible way to confirm or reject this hypothesis would be to check whcih miners mined in the last 3-5 days (usually it's in the extradata)

author: karalabe
content: and if we can correlate uncles to one specifically, maybe ask if they switch clients recently
